maml:description.maml:para: Gets active physical monitors for use with other commands in this module.

This command gets physical monitors that are currently active members of the Windows desktop. Depending on the exact monitor, it will be returned as either a VCPMonitor or a WMIMonitor object (typically internal laptop displays). WMIMonitors have limited support (only support reading and setting display brightness). VCPMonitors can generally do anything that this module offers, though the monitor itself may lack hardware support for certain features.

Specifies the Windows device name used for the logical display to find the associated physical displays. The names look like: "\.\DISPLAYX" where X is a number, starting from 1. Note that the numbers are not the same as the Windows display settings menu shows.

Skips checking if the found monitors are controlled by WMI rather than DDC/CI. Useful if you know the monitors can't be controlled with WMI and want a faster monitor lookup call, or if a monitor supports both WMI and DDC for management.
Specifies that the command should return the physical monitors associated with the primary display.

Skips checking if the found monitors are controlled by WMI rather than DDC/CI. Useful if you know the monitors can't be controlled with WMI and want a faster monitor lookup call, or if a monitor supports both WMI and DDC for management.

Specifies the Windows device name used for the logical display to find the associated physical displays. The names look like: "\.\DISPLAYX" where X is a number, starting from 1. Note that the numbers are not the same as the Windows display settings menu shows.
Specifies that the command should return the physical monitors associated with the primary display.

Skips checking if the found monitors are controlled by WMI rather than DDC/CI. Useful if you know the monitors can't be controlled with WMI and want a faster monitor lookup call, or if a monitor supports both WMI and DDC for management.
Returned if the monitor can be controlled through WMI. (Typically internal laptop displays)
Returned if the monitor cannot be controlled through WMI. DDC/CI support is not guaranteed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the primary monitor and sets the brightness to 20.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns brightness details (Min, Max and current value) for the specified monitor.
Returns brightness details (Min, Max and current value) for the specified monitor.
The monitor(s) to return brightness details for.
The monitor(s) to return brightness details for.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns brightness information for all connected monitors.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns color and contrast information about the specified display(s).
Returns color and contrast information about the specified display(s).
The monitor(s) to return color details for.
The monitor(s) to return color details for.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns color information for all connected monitors.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns details of the specified monitor(s) like DDC capabilities, firmware version, usage time, etc.

Returns details of the specified monitor(s) like DDC capabilities, firmware version, usage time, etc. The DDC capabilities are based off the monitor capability string, which some manufacturers unfortunately don't always fill out correctly.
The monitor(s) to return details for.
The monitor(s) to return details for.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns various details about all of the connected monitors.

maml:description.maml:para: Query the specified monitors for the specified VCP codes.

This command lets you query the specified monitors for the current value and max possible value for a specified VCP code. Alternatively, you can query the monitor for all supported codes with the -All parameter.
Queries the monitor for all possible VCP codes from 0-255 and returns the ones that are supported, along with their value.
The monitor(s) to return VCP code details for.
The monitor(s) to return VCP code details for.
The VCP codes (0-255) to query.
Queries the monitor for all possible VCP codes from 0-255 and returns the ones that are supported, along with their value.
The monitor(s) to return VCP code details for.
The VCP codes (0-255) to query.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all supported VCP codes by for display1.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets various monitor settings to their factory defaults.
Resets various monitor settings to their factory defaults.
The settings that should be reset.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The monitor(s) to reset settings on.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The settings that should be reset.
The monitor(s) to reset settings on.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resets all color settings for Display1.

maml:description.maml:para: Issues a command to save the current display settings on the specified monitor.
Issues a command to save the current display settings on the specified monitor.
The monitor(s) where the modified settings should be saved.
The monitor(s) where the modified settings should be saved.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Save the current settings for all connected monitors.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the monitor brightness on the specified monitors.
Sets the monitor brightness on the specified monitors. Also allows adjustment of various dynamic brightness settings for WMI displays.
The brightness value to set.
Set the ambient light sensor brightness value. If brightness has been manually adjusted, the brightness policy has to be reverted by using the RevertToPolicy parameter.

Controls whether or not brightness should be adjusted by the Ambient Light Sensor. If brightness has been manually adjusted, the brightness policy has to be reverted by using the RevertToPolicy parameter.
The monitor to adjust brightness settings for.
Reverts the brightness policy to system managed if manual brightness values have previously been used.
Sets the timeout for changing the brightness on WMIMonitors. It's rarely needed.
The brightness value to set.
The monitor to adjust brightness settings for.
Set the ambient light sensor brightness value. If brightness has been manually adjusted, the brightness policy has to be reverted by using the RevertToPolicy parameter.

Controls whether or not brightness should be adjusted by the Ambient Light Sensor. If brightness has been manually adjusted, the brightness policy has to be reverted by using the RevertToPolicy parameter.
The monitor to adjust brightness settings for.
Reverts the brightness policy to system managed if manual brightness values have previously been used.
Sets the timeout for changing the brightness on WMIMonitors. It's rarely needed.
The brightness value to set.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the brightness value to 100 on all active monitors.

maml:description.maml:para: Allows adjustment of various color related settings on the specified monitors.
Allows adjustment of various color related settings on the specified monitors.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the blue color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the blue color.
Adjusts how saturated the blue color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the overall image should be.
Changes the color temperature on the display.
Adjusts the contrast level on the display.
Adjusts how saturated the cyan color should be.
Adjusts the gamma level on the display.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the green color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the green color.
Adjusts how saturated the green color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the magenta color should be.
The monitor(s) to get color info from.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the red color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the red color.
Adjusts how saturated the red color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the yellow color should be.
Expands the gray scale in the near black region, making darks appear more light or gray. Values between 0-3 can be used.
Expands the gray scale in the near white region, making whites appear more dark or gray. Values between 0-3 can be used.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the blue color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the blue color.
Adjusts how saturated the blue color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the overall image should be.
Changes the color temperature on the display.
Adjusts the contrast level on the display.
Adjusts how saturated the cyan color should be.
Adjusts the gamma level on the display.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the green color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the green color.
Adjusts how saturated the green color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the magenta color should be.
The monitor(s) to get color info from.
Adjusts the "drive" AKA "black" level for the red color.
Adjusts the "gain" AKA "tint" level for the red color.
Adjusts how saturated the red color should be.
Adjusts how saturated the yellow color should be.
Expands the gray scale in the near black region, making darks appear more light or gray. Values between 0-3 can be used.
Expands the gray scale in the near white region, making whites appear more dark or gray. Values between 0-3 can be used.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adjusts the overall color saturation and gain for the red color on the primary display.

maml:description.maml:para: Adjusts the value of the specified VCP code with the specified value.

Adjusts the value of the specified VCP code with the specified value. This can be used to adjust any of the settings that the monitor supports, rather than the high level wrappers included in the module.
The VCP code to adjust. You can get a list of the supported VCP codes on the monitor with `Get-MonitorVCPResponse -All`.
The value to set. Read the DDC/CI documentation to find out what the value means for your specific VCP code. Alternatively, you can experiment with different values and note down the results.
The monitor(s) where the VCP code + value should be set.
The monitor(s) where the VCP code + value should be set.
The VCP code to adjust. You can get a list of the supported VCP codes on the monitor with `Get-MonitorVCPResponse -All`.
The value to set. Read the DDC/CI documentation to find out what the value means for your specific VCP code. Alternatively, you can experiment with different values and note down the results.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the VCP code 0x60 (Input select) to 3 on display3.
